last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10161309
They were quite good. This one was my favorite because it turned into a decently big and detailed R2D2 that looked very impressive on a shelf. And the ROTJ into was one of my favorite bits, so having Jabba's palace as the interior was the icing on the cake.

Some of the features here were really fun, like the trapdoor really worked to drop Luke into the rancor pit, and you could dramatically open the sliding door to let it out. Lots of fun. My only real complaint is that the environment itself is so visually dull. It's 90% brown rock, and Jabba's throne room is smooth brown walls and floors with only stickers to liven it up. It's not their fault, it's movie accurate, but still, it looks pretty boring compared to how interesting the Mighty Max interiors were.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10161894
Another good example: Vader. Cool as hell to have his mask on your shelf, and the cloud city interior is actually really well done. I also REALLY like the circular landing pad they managed to give Slave 1.

Just like the R2D2 one though, the surface sculpt is mostly pretty uninteresting. Lots of flat surfaces only held up by stickers. Not their fault, it's just the way Star Wars looks.

These were not as good as Mighty Max to me, but they were definitely second in line.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

threads.name: Morphine-Kun
threads.com:
Welcome back everyone, hope you're all doing well.

The time has come for us to finally have new releases in the line! By now most of everyone who ordered Olivier and Vania should have them in hand. Its seems the delay was worth it as Olivier seems to be one of the better releases in the line. Vania also seems to be a generally good release as people are having fun messing with her and Olivier. As of now, we only have one other figure up for Pre-Order right now, that being Bikini Clover. Currently we know that the Polynian and Touhou series will continue since Marisa is supposedly the next in line to go up. The official Poly 4Koma is still going and it seems its been well received as it gives little look into the everyday lives of the Polys we know. We also had a wonderful surprise in the form of the new Polynian MLL body! We finally have a counterpart to the Iana body. Aside from that things have been pretty quiet for the time being.

As always, here is the assistance e-mail for those who need it, so if any problem should arise, feel free to contact them over at "user_support@mile-stone.jp" or the shop you purchased the figure from.

Once again, feel free to share your photos and adventures, they add life and some fun to the thread. Also, welcome newcomers, we hope you enjoy your stay.

>plushies are easier to reproduce
>cloth-caped action figure aren't common because otherwise its price goes up
i dont understand

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10161143
Different type of cloth and you need separate part of company which will produce capes other fabrics for pure plastic toys.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10161143
-Lots more labor involved when working with cloth capes than just popping a plastic cape out of the mold. The fabric has to be cut, sewn, attached, results in longer time for QC checks as well
-Additional material needed aside from the various other plastics used for the figure
-Usually has to be sourced from a different supplier than the one supplying the plastics, introducing additional logistical headaches
-Additional safety testing needed since fabrics have standards they have to meet (fire retardation, stretch/tear resistance, dyes). Also has to be checked for loose metals (needles or pins) in the fabric by passing through xrays before leaving the factory.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

I meant metal detectors but you get the idea. Toy companies aren't just bullshitting us. The cloth capes on an otherwise plastic figure is for sure an extra cost
